pros: A wonderful place to work -- many learning/educational opportunities.

job_title: Candidate Services Representative in Toronto, ON
pros: Great team environment and Supportive management
cons: The system can be improved

pros: I worked here 2009-2011 (but the system doesn't have earlier years to choose from). It was a great PT job - the manager and other co-workers were nice and friendly, plus, you sometimes got to be inside and listen to the show.
cons: When I was here, there were quite a few ushers, so I didn't get as many shifts as I would have liked, but it did work with my main theatre work.

review_title: Great place to work, great team
pros:
- Team collaboration
- Opportunity to learn and grow
cons: - Needs more social activities to engage cross-department relations

pros:
Only work here to get some experience and move on. Unless you plan to retire while working here or just need a job for the sake of it, don’t expect to stay long-term as there are no benefits for being loyal. 

The staff (non-management) are wonderful to work with and The RCM should be lucky that they put up with the craziness.

Benefits are average.

Beautiful building and great location. Subway accessible.
cons:
Management is disorganized and decisions are made without input from employees and so unrealistic timelines and expectations are given and projects fail.

High staff turnover

There is a bit of a “boys club” with senior mgmt. There is no proper process with respect to internal job postings

Departments work in “silos”, the company is awful when it comes to relaying information about people leaving the company or when new people are hired because they fear it looks bad optically.

President is overpaid (take a look at the Sunshine list) while the staff never get raises and are over-worked.

Benefits are okay. There are no maternity/paternity top ups. You need to go on EI. Vision benefits are poor...only get eye exams no benefits for glasses or contacts. Also, you can only carry over 5 unused vacations days each year, otherwise you lose them and you don’t get paid out for them.

No career development or opportunities for growth. Performance reviews do not happen and it’s unlikely you’ll get salary increases so ask for a high salary when you start!

review_title: Senior management needs to get a clue
pros: Most of my colleagues are great to work with. Respect for work/life balance is OK. Salaries could be higher, but in terms of the cultural sector they are probably above average.
cons:
The Royal Conservatory has really gone downhill in the last few years. The organization's focus has shifted completely, and this shift has not changed things for the better. They seem interested only in money, and not in their mandate as a leader in arts and arts education anymore. Every change the organization makes seems to pander more and more to the wealthy - as donors and as customers.

There is little respect for the autonomy of employees - we're not talking just low-level employees, even the CEOs of the various components of the organization have no say in how the company is run. This is a recent shift.

The company has reduced the size of its staff, through layoffs and attrition. It is expected that remaining staff members cope with increased workloads - to do the work of the staff that is gone, and also add more projects on top of that. This is "rewarded" with stagnant salaries and threats to job security.

pros: nice building, occasional free concert ticket
cons: overlook hardworking frontline staff, friends promoted to management

pros: Highly specialized work force and require education
cons: be able to work and educated at the same time

review_title: Toxic work environment with no innovated thinking
pros:
- Colleagues are hard-working and super friendly
- Get to be inspired by musicians everyday 
- Beautiful building
cons:
- Upper management is a complete old boys club with outdated views and no strategic plan for the future
- No salary increases, bonuses or professional development
- No staff appreciation
- Outdated technology that slows down efficiency and workflow. Again, upper management does not see the value in investing in new tech. 
- Departments are set-up in silos and collaboration is not encouraged
- Upper management does not take feedback from employees and dismisses any form of criticism

pros:
Great benefits. Salary is competitive.
Amazing building at downtown location.
Great environment for those liking music. 
Complementary tickets to concerts
Great people working there.
Lots of changes so work can be interesting if you are proactive.
Can become a life-time job.
cons:
No guidance from the management. 
Lacking performance evaluation.
Poor internal communication. 
Some departments are very slow to respond to requests.

job_title: Illustrator, Animator, Designer in Toronto, ON
pros: Fun work, great management, interesting job. It felt nice to work on something educational with other creative individuals. Lots of room for creativity.
cons: No cons besides the fact that it took me an extremely long time to get paid from the date of sending out the invoice.

pros: Good people, reasonable work hours, ok benefits, clean bathrooms, good computers, matching furniture, nice location, and I enjoy being around good music.
cons: Extremely poor HR, unfair people management, poor business decisions, wasteful marketing decisions, verbal but no material recognition for good performance, no opportunity for growth within the company, extremely poor mid-to-long-term planning, constant changes of mind in marketing direction, extremely poor communication from the top down, divisions woefully understaffed and staff outrageously overworked.

review_title: No No No, don't go there! never again!!!!
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Toronto, ON
pros: No dress code,  you can wear jeans to work or even naked! snacks are always on the table provided by those rude co-workers.
cons: Unstable hours, no proper training provide by management , rude co-workers like gangsters, un-professional - no dress code, you can wear tank top,  shorts and  flip flops , vent after customer hang up and vowel languages are all over the tiny little room  9 desks- call centre, and that tiny little room filled with un-necessary conversations that you don't want to hear and  gangster style towards to newbie, no respect!

pros: Management is very supportive, understanding and accommodating. They take good care of their employees. Promotion is based on performance as opposed to seniority (at least from my understanding).
cons: For part-time positions, there isn't much room for improvement, minimum wage is not the best incentive and hours are not fixed. As with any customer service job, it can be stressful dealing with unreasonable customers who feel they are privileged and are always correct.

pros: People are nice and work/life balance is okay. Beautiful building and there are always amazing performances.
cons: Senior management is not well organized and the organization has no clear direction. The organization tries to save money by laying off staff but then turns around and wastes it on poorly managed projects. No room for growth as an employee and the workloads are unreasonable as less people are doing more work that will ultimately go unrecognized. Sounds like a great place to work but it's really just a gong show.

job_title: Prefer Not to Disclose in Toronto, ON
pros:
Access to concerts and musical performances
The building is gorgeous
Good coffee
cons:
The executive team is an old boys club
Sexist overtones - eg. certain people (men)  get promoted without jobs being properly posted for other internal applicants
The senior management don't care about retaining employees.
Raises are not common - don't count on them happening. 
Overall quite a dysfunctional organization with an uninspiring senior leadership team.

pros: The building is beautiful, the mission is great and the people are excellent
cons: Upper management is an old boys club. There isn't a ton of room for advancement and no training. Most projects are last minute and there doesn't seem to be a plan in place to make things better.

pros: So many wonderful people work here.
cons: Zero support and respect for staff. They keep increasing the C-Suite, hiring Directors and upper management while cutting the staff that are actually doing the work. Koerner Hall was nothing but a legacy project for Peter Simon, he has no regard for people who actually want to learn how to play music. The toxicity starts with him and trickles all the way down. Stay far away!

job_title: RCM Examination Representative in Toronto, ON
pros: Working with the musical community from home, having a wonderful time meeting with people from all walks of life.
cons: Working long hours, weekends. We would love to have higher pay for our time and efforts.

pros: Fair benefits and hours. Good product, beautiful building, great location, nice people.
cons: Extremely poor senior management. Lack of detailed annual planning, unrealistic goal setting, goal posts constantly changing, misguided strategy, lack of overall business acumen in senior management, no performance reviews.

review_title: A beautiful space but no way to grow

cons: Low salaries, not enough space or room for growth, not enough staff, people doing double duty and getting burnt out.

pros: Very nice and beautiful building
